item.title: Covid-19: Officials hunt Brazil virus variant case in England
item.description: One of the six cases detected remains unidentified as health officials ask people to come forward.

item.title: Budget 2021: Extra £1.6bn for UK's Covid vaccination rollout
item.description: The chancellor is to provide more funding for the programme, which has now given 20m first doses.

item.title: CPAC: Trump rules out new political party in speech to conservatives
item.description: The former US president hints at another run in 2024 as he returns to the political stage.

item.title: Golden Globe Awards 2021: Boyega and Kaluuya among British winners
item.description: Tina Fey and Amy Poehler are hosting the year's first major film and TV awards ceremony.

item.title: Yemen: The nine-year-old war-zone school teacher
item.description: Ahmed, blind since birth, stands in for teachers who don't make it in to their ruined school in Yemen.

item.title: Myanmar coup: Deadliest day of protests as police open fire
item.description: At least 18 people are killed as police try to disperse huge anti-coup rallies in several cities.

item.title: New non-fatal strangulation law to target domestic abusers
item.description: Perpetrators will face up to five years in jail under a new law planned by the government.

item.title: Covid-19: More than 20 million in UK have had first jab
item.description: The milestone is a "huge national achievement" and "every jab makes a difference", Boris Johnson says.

item.title: Family found camping on 'dangerous' cliff edge in North Yorkshire
item.description: A couple with a child had set up camp on a cliff edge in an area known for landslips.

item.title: Glenn Roeder: Former West Ham and Newcastle manager dies aged 65
item.description: Former Watford, West Ham, Newcastle and Norwich manager Glenn Roeder dies aged 65, says the League Managers Association.

item.title: Covid-19: Police break up crowd of 250 watching fight
item.description: An "organised fight" in a yard in County Tyrone was a clear breach of Covid-19 rules, say police.

item.title: Covid-19: Far-left link to Dublin lockdown protest 'disproved'
item.description: Protestors were from anti-vaccine and far-right groups, says Garda Commissioner Drew Harris.

item.title: The Papers: 'Race to stop Brazil variant' and jabs pass 20m
item.description: Many papers report the Brazil variant being found in the UK as officials "hunt" an unidentified case.

item.title: Coronavirus: False vaccine claims debunked
item.description: Misleading claims about coronavirus vaccines have been spreading online.

item.title: Kooking with a Koori: How a Sydney father's simple meals have won hearts
item.description: Aboriginal man Nathan Lyons has found unexpected fame with videos inspired by "doing it tough".

item.title: Tips for first-time runners in lockdown
item.description: Radio 1 Newsbeat finds out what you should and shouldn't be doing as a first-time runner.

item.title: Coronavirus and homelessness: 'I was living in the back of a transit van’
item.description: Alex has been homeless on and off for 10 years, and lost his job as lorry driver when the pandemic hit.

item.title: Denver family wows neighbourhood with snow art
item.description: The Mosley family spent 10 hours creating this colourful snake sculpture out of snow.

item.title: Covid: Beach car parks shut to stop lockdown rule-breakers
item.description: 'Crowds' reported as people also fined for travelling to "take pictures of their dogs together"

item.title: Coronavirus doctor's diary: Study shows one-in-three children have rarely been leaving the house
item.description: Only a third of children in Bradford had sufficient exercise during the first lockdown, a study shows.

item.title: Covid: How many people get self-isolation payments?
item.description: Figures for England and Wales suggest two-thirds of people who ask for self-isolation payments get rejected.

item.title: Waste food: What do you do with 86 tonnes of celeriac?
item.description: With hospitality closed during lockdown, charities and apps are stepping in to help cut food waste.

item.title: Sir Kazuo Ishiguro warns of young authors self-censoring out of 'fear'
item.description: Writers may be self-censoring because they don't want to be "cancelled", author Kazuo Ishiguro says.

item.title: Why this teen set up a prize-winning fake cosmetics shop
item.description: Polish teenager Krystyna Paszko's idea won an EU prize - she tells the BBC the story behind it.

item.title: The midwives braving armed gangs in Colombia
item.description: A group of Afro-Colombian women use their skills to help women give birth in areas run by gangs.

item.title: Afghanistan: A year of violence on the road to peace
item.description: On the anniversary of the US-Taliban deal, Afghanistan finds itself in a precarious state.

item.title: '100% nailed-on penalty' - Solskjaer fears referees are being swayed by 'outside influences'
item.description: Manchester United boss Ole Gunnar Solskjaer says his side should have had a "100% nailed-on" penalty in the goalless draw with Chelsea and blames "outside influences" for it not being given.

item.title: Liverpool still in 'exciting places' - Klopp after win closes gap on top four
item.description: Jurgen Klopp says Liverpool are still in "exciting places" after beating Sheffield United to end a run of four successive Premier League defeats.

item.title: Trainer Elliott admits dead horse photo is real
item.description: Leading Irish racehorse trainer Gordon Elliott says a photo circulating on social media of him posing with a dead horse is real.

item.title: England Rugby condemns online threats sent to Genge
item.description: England Rugby condemns social media abuse directed at its players after Ellis Genge said he had been sent death threats following the Six Nations defeat by Wales.

item.title: Higgins says he had 'best week' of career after thrashing O'Sullivan to win Players Championship
item.description: John Higgins says he has had the "best week" of his career after beating Ronnie O'Sullivan 10-3 in the the Players Championship final.

item.title: ‘It’s wide open' - Murphy on who will win race for the Premier League top four
item.description: Manchester United, Chelsea & Liverpool - or someone else? MOTD2 pundit Danny Murphy on who will join leaders Man City in the Premier League top four.

item.title: Why LGBT+ History Month matters to athletes
item.description: Swimmer Michael Gunning, racing driver Charlie Martin and rugby union player Florence Williams speak about why LGBT+ History Month matters.

item.title: Job applications: Tips for getting your dream job
item.description: How to make you and your CV shine as unemployment levels continue to rise.

item.title: Teen entrepreneurs: 'My friend's pug inspired my business'
item.description: Meet three teenagers who decided to set up their own businesses in lockdown.

item.title: How do I find a new job and which sectors are hiring?
item.description: Jobseekers are having a tough time at the moment, but support is available.

item.title: Unemployment rate: How many people are out of work?
item.description: The unemployment rate is rising as Covid hits different parts of the economy.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: The prime minister has announced a plan for how the lockdown will be lifted in England.

item.title: Coronavirus: How does the Covid-19 alert level system work?
item.description: The threat of Covid-19 in England is ranked through a five-level, colour-coded alert system.

item.title: Coronavirus: What is the R number and how is it calculated?
item.description: The R number is a simple but crucial figure at the heart of lockdown decisions across the UK.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: Two approved Covid vaccines are being rolled out across the UK. So when might you get one?
